questions.question: How many filing statuses are available for individual taxpayers?
questions.explanation: There are five filing statuses: (1) Single, (2) Married Filing Jointly, (3) Married Filing Separately, (4) Head of Household, and (5) Qualifying Surviving Spouse (formerly Qualifying Widow(er)).
questions.tip: 5 filing statuses: S, MFJ, MFS, HOH, QSS. Know the requirements for each.

questions.question: Filing status is generally determined as of:

options.B: The last day of the tax year
options.C: The date the return is filed
options.D: Any date chosen by the taxpayer

questions.explanation: Filing status is determined as of December 31 of the tax year. If married on December 31, you are considered married for the entire year. Exception: death of spouse during the year has special rules.
questions.tip: Filing status = status on December 31. Married on 12/31 = married for the whole year.

questions.question: To qualify as Head of Household, a taxpayer must:

options.B: Be unmarried and maintain a household for a qualifying person

questions.explanation: Head of Household requires: (1) unmarried (or considered unmarried) on December 31, (2) pay more than half the cost of maintaining a home, and (3) the home is the main home of a qualifying person for more than half the year.
questions.tip: HOH: Unmarried + pay >50% home costs + qualifying person lives there >6 months.

questions.question: The two categories of dependents are:

options.B: Qualifying child and qualifying relative

questions.explanation: There are two categories: (1) qualifying child, which has specific age, relationship, residency, and support tests, and (2) qualifying relative, which has different tests including a gross income limit.
questions.tip: Two types: Qualifying child (younger, no income limit) and qualifying relative (income limit, any age).

questions.question: A person generally cannot be claimed as a dependent if they:

options.B: File a joint return with their spouse (except to claim a refund)

questions.explanation: A person filing a joint return with their spouse generally cannot be claimed as a dependent. Exception: they can be claimed if the joint return was filed solely to claim a refund of taxes withheld.
questions.tip: Joint return test: Can't claim as dependent if they filed jointly (unless only for refund claim).

questions.question: Qualifying Surviving Spouse status is available for:

options.B: Up to 5 years after spouse's death
options.C: The 2 years following the year of spouse's death if maintaining a home for a dependent child
options.D: Only the year of the spouse's death

questions.explanation: Qualifying Surviving Spouse is available for the two tax years following the year of the spouse's death. Requirements: didn't remarry, have a dependent child, and maintained a home as the child's principal residence.
questions.tip: QSS: 2 years after death year. Need dependent child + maintain home. Same rates as MFJ.

questions.question: To be a qualifying child, the child generally must be under age:

options.B: 18 at year end
options.C: 19 at year end (or 24 if a full-time student)

questions.explanation: The age test requires the child to be under 19 at year end, or under 24 if a full-time student. No age limit applies if the child is permanently and totally disabled. Age is measured at December 31.
questions.tip: QC age: <19, or <24 if full-time student, or any age if permanently disabled.

questions.question: The residency test for a qualifying child requires the child to live with the taxpayer for:

options.B: More than half the year

questions.explanation: The residency test requires the child to live with the taxpayer for more than half the year (over 6 months). Temporary absences for school, illness, vacation, or military service count as living at home.
questions.tip: QC residency: >6 months. Temporary absences (school, vacation, military) still count.

questions.question: A qualifying relative must have gross income less than:

options.B: The standard deduction amount (adjusted annually)
options.C: The personal exemption amount ($4,700 for 2023, indexed)

questions.explanation: A qualifying relative must have gross income less than the exemption amount ($4,700 for 2023, $5,050 for 2024). This amount is indexed annually. Note: The personal exemption is suspended but this amount is still used for this test.
questions.tip: QR gross income: Less than exemption amount (~$5,000). Tax-exempt income excluded.

questions.question: The support test for a qualifying relative requires the taxpayer to provide:

options.B: At least 25% of support
options.C: More than half the person's total support for the year

questions.explanation: The taxpayer must provide more than 50% of the potential dependent's total support for the year. Support includes food, lodging, clothing, medical care, education, and similar items.
questions.tip: QR support: Taxpayer must provide >50%. Include fair rental value of lodging.

questions.question: For a qualifying child, the support test requires that the child:

options.A: Provide less than half of their own support
options.B: Receive more than half support from the taxpayer

questions.explanation: Unlike qualifying relative, the qualifying child support test only requires that the child NOT provide more than half of their own support. The taxpayer doesn't have to provide most of the support—just the child can't.
questions.tip: QC support: Child must NOT provide >50% of own support. Different from QR test!

questions.question: To qualify as Head of Household, the taxpayer must pay more than half the cost of maintaining a home. This includes:

options.B: Rent, mortgage interest, utilities, insurance, repairs, food consumed at home

questions.explanation: Cost of maintaining a home includes: rent or mortgage interest (not principal), property taxes, insurance, repairs, utilities, and food consumed in the home. It does not include clothing, education, medical, vacations, or capital items.
questions.tip: Home costs: Rent, mortgage interest, taxes, insurance, repairs, utilities, food at home. NOT clothing.

questions.question: Married Filing Separately taxpayers generally:

options.A: Have the same tax benefits as MFJ
options.B: Face limitations including loss of certain credits and lower phase-out thresholds

questions.explanation: MFS typically results in higher tax. Limitations include: no EITC, education credits reduced, child tax credit reduced, Social Security may be taxable, IRA contribution phase-outs start at $0, and both must itemize if one does.
questions.tip: MFS penalties: No EITC, limited credits, SS taxable, must both itemize or both standard deduction.

questions.question: The relationship test for a qualifying child includes all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Stepchild or foster child

questions.explanation: Qualifying child relationship includes: child, stepchild, adopted child, eligible foster child, sibling, stepsibling, half-sibling, or descendants of any of these. It does NOT include parents or grandparents (they may be qualifying relatives).
questions.tip: QC relationship: Your child, sibling, or their descendants. NOT parents (they're QR).

questions.question: A married person may be considered unmarried for Head of Household purposes if:

options.A: They file separately and lived apart from spouse for the last 6+ months of the year
options.B: They file jointly
options.C: They have been married less than one year
options.D: They simply choose to be considered unmarried

questions.explanation: A married person is 'considered unmarried' if: (1) filing separately, (2) maintained home as main home for child who is dependent for over 6 months, (3) paid over half cost of home upkeep, and (4) spouse didn't live in home last 6 months of year.
questions.tip: Considered unmarried: File MFS + lived apart last 6 months + dependent child + pay >50% home costs.

questions.question: To be a qualifying relative, the person must:

options.B: Not be a qualifying child of the taxpayer or any other taxpayer

questions.explanation: A person cannot be a qualifying relative if they are the qualifying child of any taxpayer (even if that taxpayer doesn't claim them). This prevents double-claiming and ensures proper categorization.
questions.tip: Can't be QR if person is anyone's qualifying child—even if that taxpayer doesn't claim them.

questions.conceptTested: When two can claim same child
questions.question: When two or more taxpayers can claim the same child as a qualifying child, the tiebreaker rules give priority to:

options.B: The parent, then parent with longer residency, then parent with higher AGI

questions.explanation: Tiebreaker rules: (1) parent wins over non-parent, (2) if both parents and child lived with each, parent with longer residency wins, (3) if same residency, parent with highest AGI wins, (4) if neither is parent, highest AGI wins.
questions.tip: Tiebreaker: Parent first → longer residency → higher AGI. Non-parents use AGI only.

questions.question: A multiple support agreement allows a taxpayer to claim a dependent when:

options.B: Multiple people together provide >50% of support, taxpayer provides >10%, and others waive the claim
options.D: The taxpayer is the oldest supporter

questions.explanation: A multiple support agreement (Form 2120) is used when no one person provides >50% support. Requirements: (1) group provides >50%, (2) taxpayer provides >10%, (3) each who could claim (but for >50% test) signs a waiver.
questions.tip: MSA: Group provides >50%, taxpayer provides >10%, others waive. Form 2120.

questions.question: A dependent child with only earned income must file a return if earned income exceeds:

options.B: The standard deduction amount

questions.explanation: A dependent child with only earned income must file if income exceeds the standard deduction amount (~$14,600 for 2024). Different rules apply for unearned income (often $1,250 threshold) or combined earned/unearned income.
questions.tip: Dependent filing: Earned only = exceeds standard deduction. Unearned has lower threshold (~$1,250).

questions.question: For divorced or separated parents, the child is generally the qualifying child of:

options.B: The custodial parent (parent with whom child lived longer)

questions.explanation: The custodial parent (parent with whom the child lived the majority of nights) generally has the right to claim the child as a qualifying child. The noncustodial parent can claim only if custodial parent releases the claim (Form 8332).
questions.tip: Divorced: Custodial parent claims child. Can release claim via Form 8332.

questions.question: To claim a dependent, you generally must include on your return:

options.B: The dependent's Social Security Number

questions.explanation: You must provide the dependent's Social Security Number (or ITIN or ATIN for adopted children) on your return. Failure to include a valid number will result in denial of the dependent exemption and related credits.
questions.tip: Must list dependent's SSN (or ITIN/ATIN). No number = no dependency claim.

questions.question: A person who is not related to the taxpayer can still be a qualifying relative if:

options.B: They live with the taxpayer as a member of the household for the entire year (and the relationship doesn't violate local law)

questions.explanation: The relationship test for qualifying relative can be satisfied by: (1) being in a specified relationship (child, sibling, parent, aunt, uncle, etc.), OR (2) living as a member of taxpayer's household for entire year (if not violating local law).
questions.tip: QR relationship: Specific relative OR member of household all year. Can't violate local law.

questions.question: A dependent parent qualifies a taxpayer for Head of Household status even if:

options.A: The parent lives in a separate household maintained by the taxpayer
options.B: The parent has income over $50,000
options.D: The parent files a joint return

questions.explanation: Special rule: A dependent parent doesn't have to live with the taxpayer. The taxpayer can maintain a separate home for the parent and still qualify for HOH. This is the only qualifying person who doesn't have to live with the taxpayer.
questions.tip: HOH parent exception: Dependent parent can live elsewhere (nursing home). Taxpayer must pay >50% home costs.

questions.question: When a custodial parent releases the dependency claim using Form 8332, the noncustodial parent can claim:

options.A: All benefits associated with the child
options.B: Only the child tax credit and dependency exemption, NOT head of household or EITC

questions.explanation: Form 8332 releases only the dependency exemption and child tax credit to the noncustodial parent. The custodial parent retains: Head of Household status, EITC, child and dependent care credit, and exclusion for dependent care benefits.
questions.tip: Form 8332: Noncustodial gets dependency + CTC. Custodial keeps HOH, EITC, dependent care credit.

questions.question: The kiddie tax applies to unearned income of a child who is:

options.A: Under age 18, or under 19 if not self-supporting, or under 24 if full-time student not self-supporting
options.B: Only under age 14

questions.explanation: The kiddie tax applies to children: under age 18, or under 19 who don't provide half their support, or full-time students under 24 who don't provide half their support. It taxes unearned income above a threshold at the parent's rate.
questions.tip: Kiddie tax: <18, or <19 if dependent, or <24 if student + dependent. Unearned income taxed at parent's rate.

questions.question: To be claimed as a dependent, a person generally must be:

options.B: A U.S. citizen, U.S. national, U.S. resident alien, or resident of Canada or Mexico

questions.explanation: A dependent must be a U.S. citizen, U.S. national, U.S. resident alien, or a resident of Canada or Mexico. An exception exists for certain adopted children.
questions.tip: Dependent must be: U.S. citizen/national/resident, OR Canada/Mexico resident.

questions.question: In the year a spouse dies, the surviving spouse:

options.B: May file Married Filing Jointly for that year if not remarried
options.C: Must file as Head of Household

questions.explanation: In the year of death, the surviving spouse may file MFJ with the deceased spouse (if not remarried by year end). This is often the most advantageous status. QSS status is available for the following two years if conditions are met.
questions.tip: Year of death: Can file MFJ. Years 2-3 after: QSS if conditions met. Then single/HOH.

questions.question: For a person to be a qualifying child, they must be younger than the taxpayer unless:

options.B: They are permanently and totally disabled

questions.explanation: A qualifying child must be younger than the taxpayer (or the taxpayer's spouse if filing jointly). The one exception: there is no age requirement if the person is permanently and totally disabled.
questions.tip: QC must be younger than taxpayer. Exception: Disabled = no age requirement at all.

questions.question: A dependent's standard deduction is limited to the greater of $1,250 or:

options.B: Earned income plus $400, up to the regular standard deduction amount

questions.explanation: A dependent's standard deduction is the greater of: (1) $1,250 (2024), or (2) earned income plus $400, not to exceed the regular standard deduction. This prevents dependents with no/low earned income from using the full standard deduction.
questions.tip: Dependent's standard deduction: Greater of $1,250 OR (earned income + $400), capped at regular amount.

questions.question: For the qualifying relative gross income test, gross income includes:

options.B: Social Security benefits (fully included)

questions.explanation: Gross income for the QR test includes all taxable income: wages, interest, dividends, net self-employment income, taxable Social Security. It excludes tax-exempt income, nontaxable Social Security, and gifts.
questions.tip: QR gross income: Include taxable income (wages, SE income, taxable SS). Exclude tax-exempt amounts.

questions.question: For the support test, total support includes all EXCEPT:

options.B: Clothing and medical expenses

questions.explanation: Support includes: food, lodging (at fair rental value), clothing, education, medical, recreation, transportation, and similar necessities. Scholarships received by full-time students are NOT included in total support calculations.
questions.tip: Support includes everything needed to live. Scholarships excluded for full-time students.

questions.question: In a community property state, married taxpayers filing separately:

options.A: Each report only their own income
options.B: Generally must each report half of community income
options.D: Report all income to the higher earner

questions.explanation: In community property states (AZ, CA, ID, LA, NV, NM, TX, WA, WI), MFS filers generally must each report half of community property income. Separate property income is reported by the earning spouse.
questions.tip: Community property + MFS: Split community income 50/50. Separate property stays with owner.

questions.question: A child born alive on December 31 may be claimed as a dependent for:

options.B: The entire year, if all other tests are met

questions.explanation: A child born alive any time during the year, even on December 31, may be claimed as a dependent for the entire year if all tests are met. Similarly, a child who dies during the year may be claimed if tests were met while alive.
questions.tip: Born any day = full year dependent (if tests met). Death during year = still claimable if qualified.

questions.question: For Head of Household, a married child can be a qualifying person if:

options.B: You can claim the child as a dependent (child doesn't file joint return or files only for refund)
options.C: The child's spouse has no income
options.D: The child has been married less than one year

questions.explanation: A married child can be a qualifying person for HOH if the taxpayer can claim the child as a dependent. This requires the child to not file a joint return (exception: filed only to claim refund). Other qualifying child tests must be met.
questions.tip: Married child for HOH: Only if you can claim them as dependent (joint return test applies).

questions.conceptTested: Dependent for CTC vs other purposes
questions.question: For the Child Tax Credit, a qualifying child must meet all qualifying child tests AND:

options.B: Be under age 17 at the end of the year

questions.explanation: The Child Tax Credit has an additional age requirement: the qualifying child must be under age 17 at the end of the year. This is younger than the general qualifying child age test (under 19, or 24 if student).
questions.tip: CTC: Regular QC tests PLUS under age 17 at year end. Stricter than dependency age.
